lines.text: You must come up and launch with me sometime.
Then just what is it you want, Mr. Swanson?
The show I wrote. It has a point of view, not just a view of points.
Yeah, I know where to reach you - back in 1912, under a ton a stale ideas.
But it's not just me alone; its John too, its like a couple of fellas in a partnership in the corner grocery store.
You know, maybe you should be in the grocery business!

[Hearing the cheers of the crowd who've been promised a kiss from the beautiful star]
You hear that? That's the voice of the people!

[Sardonically]
Sounds more like the call of the wild.

[after kissing hundreds of shipyard workers]
Now I know how a trumpeteer feels!

[Referring to his jalopy]
I know this looks like a traveling scrap heap, but it's really poetry on wheels.

[Dryly, as the engine makes grinding noises]
I see what you mean.

[Annoyed]
Any show of mine has to stand on its own legs and not Julie Hampton's!
